      • fromCallable

        public static <T> Stream<T> fromCallable(@Nonnull Callable<T> callable)
        Creates an infinite stream that emits items from the Callable parameter. The user must be very careful to add a subsequent stream stage that cancels the stream otherwise this source will result in an infinite loop.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of items contained in the stream.
        Parameters:
        callable - the function that generates values to emit.
        Returns:
        the new stream.

        the new stream.

      • fromRunnable

        public static <T> Stream<T> fromRunnable(@Nonnull Runnable runnable)
        Creates a stream that completes when the Runnable parameter completes running. The stream will signal an error if the runnable generates an error while running.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of items that the stream declared as containing (despite never containing any items).
        Parameters:
        runnable - the runnable to execute.
        Returns:
        the new stream.

                                     int period)
        Creates an infinite stream that emits items from the Supplier parameter at specified period. The user must be very careful to add a subsequent stream stage that cancels the stream otherwise this source will result in an infinite loop.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of items contained in the stream.
        Parameters:
        supplier - the function that generates values to emit.
        period - the period with which items are emitted.
        Returns:
        the new stream.

      • create

        public static <T> Stream<T> create(@Nonnull SourceCreator<T> createFunction)
        Creates a stream using a simple function. THe function will simplify the creation of stream sources. In particular it eliminates the need to maintain the state for subscription and will handle cancelled subscriptions by ignoring calls when in cancelled state. While the code has a better developer experience, it may introduce a slightly worse runtime experience.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of items that the stream contains.
        Parameters:
        createFunction - the function for creating the source.
        Returns:
        the new stream.

      • create

        public static <T> Stream<T> create(@Nullable String name,
                                   @Nonnull SourceCreator<T> createFunction)
        Creates a stream using a simple function. THe function will simplify the creation of stream sources. In particular it eliminates the need to maintain the state for subscription and will handle cancelled subscriptions by ignoring calls when in cancelled state. While the code has a better developer experience, it may introduce a slightly worse runtime experience.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of items that the stream contains.
        Parameters:
        name - a human consumable name for the stream.
        createFunction - the function for creating the source.
        Returns:
        the new stream.

      • distinct

        @Nonnull public final Stream<T> distinct()
        Filter the items if they have been previously emitted. To determine whether an item has been previous emitted the Object.equals(Object) and Object.hashCode() must be correctly implemented for items type.

        WARNING: It should be noted that every distinct item is retained until the stream completes. As a result this operator can cause significant amount of memory pressure if many distinct items exist or the stream persists for a long time.

        Returns:
        the new stream.

      • distinct

        @Nonnull public final Stream<T> distinct(@Nullable String name)
        Filter the items if they have been previously emitted. To determine whether an item has been previous emitted the Object.equals(Object) and Object.hashCode() must be correctly implemented for items type.

        WARNING: It should be noted that every distinct item is retained until the stream completes. As a result this operator can cause significant amount of memory pressure if many distinct items exist or the stream persists for a long time.

        Parameters:
        name - the name specified by the user.
        Returns:
        the new stream.

      • take

        @Nonnull public final Stream<T> take(int maxSize)
        Truncate the stream, ensuring the stream is no longer than maxSize items in length. If maxSize is reached then the item will be passed downstream, the downstream will be completed and then the upstream will be cancelled. This method is an alias for limit(int)
        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the new stream.
        See Also:
        limit(int)

        @Nonnull public final Stream<T> last()

        Returns:

      • last

        @Nonnull public final Stream<T> last(int maxElements)
        Drop all items except for the last maxElements items. This operator will buffer up to maxElements items until it receives the complete signal and then it will send all the buffered items and the complete signal. If less than maxElements are emitted by the upstream then it is possible for the downstream to receive less than maxElements items.
        Parameters:
        maxElements - the maximum number
        Returns:
        the new stream.

      • last

        @Nonnull public final Stream<T> last(@Nullable String name,
                                     int maxElements)
        Drop all items except for the last maxElements items. This operator will buffer up to maxElements items until it receives the complete signal and then it will send all the buffered items and the complete signal. If less than maxElements are emitted by the upstream then it is possible for the downstream to receive less than maxElements items.
        Parameters:
        name - the name specified by the user.
        maxElements - the maximum number
        Returns:
        the new stream.

      • takeLast

        @Nonnull public final Stream<T> takeLast(int maxElements)
        Drop all items except for the last maxElements items. This operator will buffer up to maxElements items until it receives the complete signal and then it will send all the buffered items and the complete signal. If less than maxElements are emitted by the upstream then it is possible for the downstream to receive less than maxElements items. This method is an alias for the last(int) method.
        Parameters:
        maxElements - the maximum number
        Returns:
        the new stream.
        See Also:
        last(int)

      • skipWhile

        @Nonnull public final Stream<T> skipWhile(@Nonnull Predicate<? super T> predicate)
        Drop items from this stream until an item no longer matches the supplied predicate. As long as the predicate returns true, no items will be emitted from this stream. Once the first item is encountered for which the predicate returns false, all subsequent items will be emitted, and the predicate will no longer be invoked. This is equivalent to skipUntil(Predicate) if the predicate is negated.
        Parameters:
        predicate - The predicate.
        Returns:
        the new stream.
        See Also:
        skipUntil(Predicate)

      • skipWhile

        @Nonnull public final Stream<T> skipWhile(@Nullable String name,
                                          @Nonnull Predicate<? super T> predicate)
        Drop items from this stream until an item no longer matches the supplied predicate. As long as the predicate returns true, no items will be emitted from this stream. Once the first item is encountered for which the predicate returns false, all subsequent items will be emitted, and the predicate will no longer be invoked. This is equivalent to skipUntil(Predicate) if the predicate is negated.
        Parameters:
        name - the name specified by the user.
        predicate - The predicate.
        Returns:
        the new stream.
        See Also:
        skipUntil(Predicate)

      • skipUntil

        @Nonnull public final Stream<T> skipUntil(@Nonnull Predicate<? super T> predicate)
        Drop items from this stream until an item matches the supplied predicate. As long as the predicate returns false, no items will be emitted from this stream. Once the first item is encountered for which the predicate returns true, all subsequent items will be emitted, and the predicate will no longer be invoked. This is equivalent to skipWhile(Predicate) if the predicate is negated.
        Parameters:
        predicate - The predicate.
        Returns:
        the new stream.
        See Also:
        skipWhile(Predicate)

      • takeWhile

        @Nonnull public final Stream<T> takeWhile(@Nonnull Predicate<? super T> predicate)
        Return items from this stream until an item fails to match the supplied predicate. As long as the predicate returns true, items will be emitted from this stream. Once the first item is encountered for which the predicate returns false, the stream will be completed and the upstream canceled. This is equivalent to takeUntil(Predicate) if the predicate is negated.
        Parameters:
        predicate - The predicate.
        Returns:
        the new stream.
        See Also:
        takeUntil(Predicate)

      • skipRepeats

        @Nonnull public final Stream<T> skipRepeats()
        Drops items from the stream if they are equal to the previous item emitted by the stream. The items are tested for equality using the Objects.equals(Object, Object) method. It is equivalent to invoking filterSuccessive(SuccessivePredicate) passing a SuccessivePredicate filters out successive items that are equal.
        Returns:
        the new stream.

      • skipRepeats

        @Nonnull public final Stream<T> skipRepeats(@Nullable String name)

        the new stream.

      • filterSuccessive

        @Nonnull public final Stream<T> filterSuccessive(@Nonnull SuccessivePredicate<T> predicate)
        Filter consecutive items emitted by this stream using the specified SuccessivePredicate. Any candidate items that return true when passed to the Predicate will be emitted while all other items will be skipped. The predicate passes the last emitted item as well as the candidate item.
        Parameters:
        predicate - the comparator to determine whether two successive items are equal.
        Returns:
        the new stream.

        the new stream.

      • concatMap

        @Nonnull public final <DownstreamT> Stream<DownstreamT> concatMap(@Nonnull Function<T,Stream<DownstreamT>> mapper)
        Map each input item to a stream and then concatenate the items emitted by the mapped stream into this stream. The method operates on a single stream at a time and the result is a concatenation of items emitted from all the streams returned by the mapper function. This method is equivalent to mergeMap(Function, int) with a maxConcurrency set to 1.
        Type Parameters:
        DownstreamT - the type of the items that the mapper function emits.
        Parameters:
        mapper - the function to map the items to the inner stream.
        Returns:
        the new stream.
        See Also:
        mergeMap(Function, int)

      • mergeMap

        @Nonnull public final <DownstreamT> Stream<DownstreamT> mergeMap(@Nonnull Function<T,Stream<DownstreamT>> mapper,
                                                                 int maxConcurrency)
        Map each input item to a stream and then flatten the items emitted by that stream into this stream. The items are merged concurrently up to the maximum concurrency specified by maxConcurrency. Thus items from different inner streams may be interleaved with other streams that are currently active or subscribed.

        If an input item is received when the merged stream has already subscribed to the maximum number of inner streams as defined by the maxConcurrency parameter then the extra items are placed on an unbounded buffer. This can lead to significant memory pressure and out of memory conditions if the upstream emits items at a faster rate than the merge stream can complete the inner streams.

        Type Parameters:
        DownstreamT - the type of the items that the mapper function emits.
        Parameters:
        mapper - the function to map the items to the inner stream.
        maxConcurrency - the maximum number of inner stream that can be subscribed to at one time.
        Returns:
        the new stream.
        See Also:
        mergeMap(Function)

      • mergeMap

        @Nonnull public final <DownstreamT> Stream<DownstreamT> mergeMap(@Nonnull Function<T,Stream<DownstreamT>> mapper)
        Map each input item to a stream and flatten the items emitted by the inner stream into this stream. The number of streams that can be flattened concurrently is specified by DEFAULT_MERGE_CONCURRENCY. Invoking this method is equivalent to invoking mergeMap(Function, int) and passing the DEFAULT_MERGE_CONCURRENCY constant as the maxConcurrency parameter.
        Type Parameters:
        DownstreamT - the type of the items that the mapper function emits.
        Parameters:
        mapper - the function to map the items to the inner stream.
        Returns:
        the new stream.
        See Also:
        mergeMap(Function, int)

      • switchMap

        @Nonnull public final <DownstreamT> Stream<DownstreamT> switchMap(@Nonnull Function<T,Stream<DownstreamT>> mapper)
        Map each input item to a stream and emit the items from the most recently mapped stream. The stream that the input item is mapped to is the active stream and all items emitted on the active stream are merged into this stream. If the active stream completes then it is no longer the active stream but this stream does not complete. If a new input item is received while there is an active stream is present then the active stream is canceled and the new input item is mapped to a new stream that is made active.
        Type Parameters:
        DownstreamT - the type of the items that this stream emits.
        Parameters:
        mapper - the function to map the items to the inner stream.
        Returns:
        the new stream.

      • exhaustMap

        @Nonnull public final <DownstreamT> Stream<DownstreamT> exhaustMap(@Nonnull Function<T,Stream<DownstreamT>> mapper)
        Map each input item to a stream and emit the items from the most recently mapped stream. The stream that the input item is mapped to is the active stream and all items emitted on the active stream are merged into this stream. If the active stream completes then it is no longer the active stream but this stream does not complete. If a new input item is received while there is an active stream is present then the active stream is canceled and the new input item is mapped to a new stream that is made active.
        Type Parameters:
        DownstreamT - the type of the items that this stream emits.
        Parameters:
        mapper - the function to map the items to the inner stream.
        Returns:
        the new stream.

      • append

        @SafeVarargs
 @Nonnull public final Stream<T> append(@Nonnull Stream<T>... streams)

        the new stream.
        See Also:

      • prepend

        @SafeVarargs
 @Nonnull public final Stream<T> prepend(@Nonnull Stream<T>... streams)
        Merge the items from the specified streams before the items from this stream sequentially. For each of the supplied streams, emit all items from the stream until it completes an then move to the next stream. If no more streams have been supplied then emit the items from this stream.
        Parameters:
        streams - the stream to prepend to this stream.
        Returns:
        the new stream.
        See Also:
        prepend(Stream[])

      • publish

        @Nonnull public final ConnectableStream<T> publish()

The new stream subscribes to this stream when the ConnectableStream.connect() method is called.

      • publishCurrentValue

        @Nonnull public final ConnectableStream<T> publishCurrentValue(@Nonnull T initialValue)
        Create a multicast, ConnectableStream that shares a single subscription to this stream. The created stream emits the current value to downstream Subscribers and then emits items any items that are emitted subsequent to the time that the downstream Subscriber subscribes. The current value is the last emitted value or the initialValue if no value has been emitted by the upstream. The new stream subscribes to this stream when the ConnectableStream.connect() method is called.
        Parameters:
        initialValue - the initial value.
        Returns:
        the new stream.

      • publishReplay

        @Nonnull public final ConnectableStream<T> publishReplay()
        Create a multicast, ConnectableStream that shares a single subscription to this stream. The created stream buffers and replays events to new Subscribers and then emits events to the new subscriber as they are received. The buffering is not unbound and the developer should be careful to avoid excessive memory pressure.
        Returns:
        the new stream.

      • share

        @Nonnull public final Stream<T> share()
        Create a stream that multicasts the source Stream. As long as there is at least one Subscriber this stream will be subscribed to the source Stream and emitting data. When all subscribers have unsubscribed it will unsubscribe from the source Stream.

        the new stream.

      • share

        @Nonnull public final Stream<T> share(@Nullable String name)
        Create a stream that multicasts the source Stream. As long as there is at least one Subscriber this stream will be subscribed to the source Stream and emitting data. When all subscribers have unsubscribed it will unsubscribe from the source Stream.
        Parameters:
        name - the name specified by the user.
        Returns:
        the new stream.

      • defaultIfEmpty

        @Nonnull public final Stream<T> defaultIfEmpty(@Nonnull T defaultValue)
        If upstream emits no items and then completes then emit the defaultValue before completing this stream.
        Parameters:
        defaultValue - the public final value to emit if upstream completes and is empty.
        Returns:
        the new stream.

                                               @Nonnull T defaultValue)

        Parameters:

      • timeout

        @Nonnull public final Stream<T> timeout(int timeoutTime)
        Signals error with a TimeoutException if an item is not emitted within the specified timeout period from the previous item.
        Parameters:
        timeoutTime - the timeout period after which the stream is terminated.
        Returns:
        the new stream.

                                        int timeoutTime)

        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • compose

        @Nonnull public final <DownstreamT,S extends Stream<DownstreamT>> S compose(@Nonnull Function<Stream<T>,S> function)
        Compost this stream with another stream and return the new stream. This method is used to compose chains of stream operations.
        Type Parameters:
        DownstreamT - the type of the item emitted by downstream stage.
        S - the type of the downstream stage.
        Parameters:
        function - the function used to compose stream operations.
        Returns:
        the new stream.
